Rabies cases increase in northeastern Thailand

Dr. Thawichai, a veterinarian from the 9th Disease Prevention and Control Office, announced on February 9 that there has been an increase in rabies infections in northeastern Thailand over the past few months, with a total of 74 people infected.

So far this year (from October last year to September this year), there have been 74 people who tested positive for rabies in the northeastern provinces of Surin and Buri Ram, with 67 in Surin and 7 in Buri Ram.
Everyone has had rabies vaccine in the past.
The doctor is urging people to get vaccinated against rabies along with their pets, and to avoid touching the saliva of animals suspected of having the disease.
Rabies is not only transmitted by dogs, but also by cats and bats.
If a person is infected and develops the disease, almost 100% will die, but if they are vaccinated before they develop the disease, they can be saved.

Fujii (head office in Chiryu city) which deals with the installation of electronic components and the manufacturing and sales of robots and machinery, has started developing a system to prevent "leaving behind" such as children being left in cars.
A motion sensor is installed in the car, and when it detects movement, it sends a notification to the phone or chat.
Currently, we are conducting a trial using our own vehicles.
In the midst of accidents caused by abandonment, protect the safety of children.
Currently, in Chiryu City, the company operates an after-school English conversation school for children, "Terakoya San-kyo" (Terakoya San-kyo), and is conducting a trial run with two buses.
Three motion sensors that detect movement by the difference in temperature between the person and the surrounding environment were installed on the ceiling of the car.
When the vehicle engine is turned off and the door is closed for a certain period of time, it automatically sends a warning notification when it detects human movement.
By linking the state of the engine and the door to information, it is possible to prevent false alarms as much as possible.
The warning was issued through the cloud.

"If we can expand our solutions, we will."

An employee with young children has proposed something that could be done to protect the safety of children.
We decided to develop a system that utilizes the know-how gained through our FA (factory automation) business, such as IoT (Internet of Things) and information management using sensors.

The city planning centered around the new station will take a long time to reach a consensus among citizens. (City official)

There is a sense of opacity in the extension of the line to the west of Daidō, before the new station.

Chocolate sales area revived for the first time in 3 years for Valentine's Day = Seibu Fukui store in Fukui, Fukui Prefecture on February 9th

As the price of chocolate rises due to the increase in raw materials and packaging materials before Valentine's Day on February 14th, sales of "self-praise chocolate" and chocolate for family and friends in the high price range are doing well.
In convenience stores and confectionery stores in Fukui Prefecture, products are being promoted with a focus on local color, luxury, and attention to materials, in an effort to attract customers.
Seibu Fukui (Fukui City) opened a special sales floor on the 6th floor on January 25th.
By the 14th, they will have sold around 40 brands and 50 varieties of sweets in 10 stores across the prefecture.
There is a high demand for products such as chocolate and cookies made with Fukui sake, which contain fresh chocolate and sand-like ingredients.
According to the store manager, the price of the goods on the store floor has risen by about 10% compared to the previous year.

This year's trend is "focusing on ingredients and packaging, and there are many products that stand out. The consumer trend is that they buy it for themselves and their families, and enjoy comparing them."
Even in the midst of a price hike backlash, high-priced items are selling well.

"We are focusing on creating a sales channel where people can enjoy the Valentine's Day event itself," said the official.
In the same store, they have been selling recommended sweets on a rotating basis since January 26th, and they have also restarted tastings for the first time in three years.

The Western confectionery club (Kurabu) (head office: Sakai-city Maruoka-cho Ichi-no-chome) has for the first time introduced its original chocolate "Kiseki" (miracle) series, which it developed in collaboration with a long-established French chocolate maker, into the Valentine's Day battle.
The cocoa beans are carefully selected, and the fruity taste is balanced with a slight bitterness, and they are sold in packs of 3 for 1,000 yen and packs of 9 for 3,000 yen.

"The culture of giri choco is gradually disappearing, but there is a need for a little bit of fun on Valentine's Day. We will increase the value of our products and differentiate ourselves," said Takahara, the president of the purchasing department.

The cat-shaped feeding robot introduced at "Ishizushi-age Jingisukan Bon-ta Fukui Station Store"
Faces that look like they're from another world are popular with families at Fukui, Fukui-shi, Ote 2-chome.
In the food and beverage industry in Fukui Prefecture, where there is a shortage of labor, there is a trend to introduce delivery robots that bring food to the table.

The robots are popular with families, as they can help with the store's efforts to reduce the number of people working and prevent the spread of the new coronavirus, and they can also display expressions that are cute and appealing.
Restaurant owners and their associates say, "It is difficult to secure employees and part-time workers in local restaurants, so the spread of delivery robots is inevitable."
"Jin, Jin, Jin-gi-su-khan!"
A robot that plays light music and displays a cat's face on the screen while carrying a dish and smoothly moving around the store.
When you arrive at the table, you say things like "I brought your order" to the customers.
The "Ishiru-nuru Jingisukan-bon Fukui Station" store, located at 2-chome, Ota, Fukui, introduced a cat-shaped feeding robot in August 2022.
A robot waits near the kitchen and when a customer orders something on the screen, it will go to the table and deliver the food.
AI (artificial intelligence) voice function and other features are built in, so it reacts when touched by the user, and the cat face on the screen has a wide range of expressions.
The "Bonta Group," which operates the same store, has introduced meal delivery robots in two stores including this store.
Chairman Saotome emphasized that the reason for the introduction is "lack of manpower", and that it is a part of the productivity improvement by depopulation and digital transformation (DX).
The ratio of labor costs to sales is usually around 30%, but it can be reduced by up to 21-22% by introducing it.

In addition to collecting plates after customers finish eating, it is also efficient for cleaning up after meals, and it is also said that "families and children like it, and it also has a promotional effect."
The "Rokkan Hoshiyama Fukui Store" of the grilled meat and hot pot restaurant "Rokkan Hoshiyama Fukui" in Araki Shinpo-cho, Fukui City, also introduced a meal-making robot in August 22 years ago.

Hoshiyama Eifuku, the president of the Sansan store Hoshiyama Eifuku, said, "I couldn't find employees or part-timers even if I recruited them. I thought it was absolutely necessary to solve the shortage of manpower."
The Fukui store divides the area where employees serve food and the area where robots deliver food.
The cost of leasing a robot is the same as the salary of one part-time worker.
In order to reduce the number of people, the store is considering installing a tablet-based ordering system in addition to robots, and is also considering introducing self-checkout.

According to the Fukui Labor Bureau, the effective recruitment ratio for the "customer service" category, including restaurants, was 6.94 times in December 2022, making it a job category with a high shortage of personnel.

The person in charge of the online system (located at Takagi Chuo 2-chome, Fukui) that acts as a sales agent for meal delivery robots said, "The impact of the coronavirus has worsened the shortage of labor in Fukui's restaurants, and we have received many inquiries about introducing robots."
Hoshiyama president said, "I think it will be harder to secure employees for local suburban stores in the future, and I think delivery robots will become more common."
[Opinion] Echizen Town creates an ending note and distributes it to the citizens who hope for it.

Last year, they published a comprehensive "ghost handbook" that covers the procedures and writing styles needed when someone in the family dies, as well as a family tree, and they were surprised at how many people wanted to buy it for themselves.
Ending notes writing and pre-death preparation classes are held in various places in the prefecture, and "death" seems to have become firmly established in the minds of the people.
The ending note of Echizen is 35 pages.

The fifth chapter begins with a summary of your personal history and then goes on to describe your current health and financial situation, your wishes for future care, your hopes for end-of-life medical care, and your wishes for your funeral and burial.
There is also a section for things you want to do in the rest of your life and messages to important people.
It says it's 35 pages long, but it looks like it's going to break my spine, I don't need to fill every page.
What do you want to write down for your family and the people around you?
The important thing is to make the purpose clear.
Various colorful notes are sold at bookstores and the like, and you can start writing them anywhere you can write.
The term "end of life" was born in 2009 when I started working.
The Great East Japan Earthquake occurred in 2011, two years later.
It is said that many people have come to face the reality that "death comes suddenly" and that the number of people who prepare for their final days and end of life has increased.
That was 10 years ago.
The new coronavirus that has swept the world is still not under control.
Prices have risen due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and this winter's electricity prices have jumped to unbelievable heights.
On the other hand, wages have not risen as much as prices, and many people are struggling to keep up.

On the other hand, funeral expenses and nursing care expenses that used to be shared by the family and relatives, as well as the management of the grave, are becoming more and more difficult for a single child in this day and age.
We're living longer than ever before, but as we age, the risk of dementia and needing care increases, creating a dilemma.
I want to keep in mind that this social anxiety is also growing in a society where death is not a one-time event but a permanent background.
Either way, I think most people would agree that they don’t want to put an undue burden on their partners or children.
"Dying with dignity" is a popular phrase from the endgame notes, but it can't be too self-centered.
I don't want to write it down and hide it, but I want to talk to my family about it and be prepared for that moment.

At the graduation ceremony, it was decided that masks were not necessary for children and students, as well as teachers, as a general rule = 10th February, Saitama Prefecture, Toda City
The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided on February 10 that students should not wear masks at graduation ceremonies.

The principal of a large middle school said, "It's difficult to keep a distance between students, and I'm worried about how to deal with it. There are also students who feel uneasy about taking off their masks."
After the news that masks were worn at graduation ceremonies, this topic is also being discussed among teachers.
However, one principal said, "If the government says so, we will have to comply. We cannot realistically respond if we exclude singing."

At this graduation ceremony, they allowed students who had been self-isolating to attend, and restarted the graduation song sung by graduates, and there were also movements to ease the countermeasures of some schools in the prefecture.
In the prefecture, the prefectural high school will hold its graduation ceremony in late March, and the public junior high school will hold its graduation ceremony in mid-March.
The prefectural and municipal boards of education are waiting for official notification from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology before deciding on their response.

In addition, there have been calls for caution regarding the Ministry of Education's decision to not require masks to be worn in school education activities from the start of the new term this spring.

The principal of the elementary school said, "Children may be confused if they suddenly stop wearing masks. First, I decided to say, 'You can wear or not wear a mask at your own discretion,' and then gradually more children started taking off their masks.'

The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided on February 10 that masks will not be required in school education activities from April, following the government's new guidelines on wearing masks.
It is generally not required to wear a mask during singing, physical education classes, or club activities.

In the middle of 2022, we will request infection prevention measures based on the current health management manual, and we will disseminate the points to be noted from April onwards to the Education Committee and the school site.

Graduation ceremonies for elementary, middle, and high schools, as well as universities, will be held in the 2022 academic year, but measures such as air circulation will be taken, and graduates, teachers, and students attending will not be required to wear masks.

NPO Corporation "Kokoro-Nakushi Bunsho-Henshu Kyoku" self-published book "Dear Prime Minister, "Life's Breakwater" from Toshinbo"
I have published my 10th book, "Dear Prime Minister, from Tōjinbō, a breakwater of life", under the title of self-publishing.
Many readers have sent in their thoughts, and all the newspapers have covered it.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the content that I have directly heard from the person who attempted suicide in Japan, about the social and structural environmental issues that are the cause of suicide, and to create a society that is good for living.

For 18 years and 10 months, we have been patrolling the cliffs of Tōjinbō in Fukui Prefecture, which is known as a suicide spot, to prevent suicide by providing support to those who are planning to commit suicide until they are ready to start over.

This book is a summary of the issues heard from the 784 people (2/6 currently) who have been protected, and I would like to appeal to the Prime Minister as a necessary measure to prevent suicide, the following seven points.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) Behind suicide, there is a mountain of "human rights violation".
(3) The suicide is a victim of social and structural organized crime.
(4) The administrative organs treat citizens who live outside their jurisdiction as "others" and treat them with disdain.
(5) Mental patients such as depression are drugged and treated as "accidents" even if they commit suicide.
(6) The "duty of care" for safety in high risk areas of suicide has been forgotten and commercialism is running rampant.
(7) The teachings of new religions that cannot be scientifically proven are lies, and the act of telling the future and threatening the other party while demanding gold is extortion.
The religious organization that commits the crime of "fraud and intimidation" should be publicly announced and excluded.

In this section, I will introduce some of the comments we received from readers who purchased this book, such as "I was moved by the strong mental fortitude of those who are involved in this activity," "The former police officer's attitude is something to be admired by police officers," and "I am amazed that there are people who support others to that extent, even though they are not related to them, and that they are living as bodhisattvas."
I was moved to tears when I saw the photo in the newspaper article.
I've heard that suicides are increasing among people who are being pushed into a corner by the corona crisis.
That's really sad.
They are all just like that.
I want to live in a society where I can live happily with my own life.
I have a great deal of respect and gratitude for the staff who have given their all to those who are suffering so much.
I think this activity is very hard on the body and mind, so I ask that you please continue to speak out for yourself.
thank you.
kashiko
I hope that all of you readers will become gatekeepers of life in your respective regions.

Toba City to double child-rearing household allowance payments, but some want refunds - Ise Newspaper
[Toba] Toba City announced on the 10th that a total of 600,000 yen was mistakenly paid to 11 households with a total of 12 people in the special subsidy for child-rearing households in fiscal 2020.
The city is demanding a procedure for the return of the items while apologizing and explaining the circumstances.
According to the city, the issue was discovered on January 27, 2020, when the guardian of a child who had previously made a deposit went to confirm the amount.
Confirming the situation of all beneficiaries in the same year, it was found that 12 people in 11 households received double payment of the benefit on July 20, 2020.
The city will provide a 50,000 yen subsidy to each child under high school age in households exempt from residential tax.

The data was provided by a computer processing company that was entrusted with extracting the target children from the data, but the employee in charge mistakenly thought that the data did not contain high school students and added it to the data, resulting in double payment.
The staff of the city's childcare support room said, "We will strictly stop it, check the data again, and make every effort to prevent recurrence and regain trust."
Soft tennis tournament held for the third year in a row, women's team selection held at Yokkaichi Dome - Ise Shimbun
[Athletes who practiced the day before = at Yokkaichi Dome in Yokkaichi City, Feudal Japan]

The 37th Dunlop Cup All-Japan Women's Team Selection Soft Tennis Tournament (organized by the All-Japan Women's Team Strengthening Committee, sponsored by Ise Shimbun, etc.) will be held for the first time in three years on the 11th and 12th at Yokkaichi Dome in Yokkaichi City, Matsuzaka.
23 groups and 24 teams, including local businesses and universities, will participate in the tournament, with the Japan Women's League team at the center.
Held annually since 1986 with the aim of raising the level of play until the start of the Japan League, the venue has been Yokkaichi Dome since 1998.
It has been suspended for two years since 2021 due to the influence of the new coronavirus, and this year it will be held for the third time in three years.

24 teams are divided into 8 blocks and the first league (preliminary round) is held from 9am to 11am on the 11th, followed by the second league (semi-final) from around 3pm on the 11th, which consists of 12 matches, and the remaining matches and position determination games of the second league are held from 9am to 12pm on the 12th.
Two teams from Mie Prefecture, Mie High School and Mie Prefecture Selection, will be participating in the tournament, aiming for a top 8 finish.

Introducing the pioneers of plant research, including data from Mount Hayachine, at the city's comprehensive cultural property center planning exhibition [Hanaoka] | Iwanichi Online | Iwate Nippo Shimbunsha

An exhibition that introduces the people who laid the foundation for the study of the plants on Mount Hayachine, a mountain known for its alpine flora, is being held at the city's comprehensive cultural property center in Hasama, Hanamaki, until the 12th.
The 124th point of the collection of valuable specimens collected by predecessors and data, and the footprints of the predecessors who were involved in the research on the plants of Mount Hayachine.

The botanical research on Mount Hayachine began with the arrival of Russian botanist Karl Johann Maximovitch (1827-1915) in the late Edo period, and continued with Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), who collected plants under Maximovitch's guidance.

Maximo Viti, who was not allowed to walk freely in the country because he was a foreigner, asked Sugawa to collect information and conducted research for three years in Yokohama and Nagasaki as a base.

Nukawa continued to support research even after Maximo's return to Japan, and was involved in the announcement of the "Himekozakura", "Nanbouuchisou", and "Miyamayamabishouma", which are unique to Mount Hayachine.

After that, modern botanist Makino Tomitaro (1862–1957) published “Bistorta hayachinensis”, “Cobanotusmeckesia”, “Draba japonica”, and “Arenaria katoana”, which were collected by local researchers, in 1903 (Meiji 36), and “Katoana” in 1905 (Meiji 38),
From the display data, it can be seen that many researchers have discovered valuable alpine plants.

In addition, the authors introduce the activities of Shimura Matsuzo (1874-1948), principal of Hanaoka Elementary School who accompanied the investigation into the preservation of natural monuments in 1927, and Tamagawa Seichi (1914-1988), curator of the Hasama Town Museum of Natural History, who was involved in the publication of "Plants of Mt. Hakone

Yoshida Muneo, a researcher at the center, said, "There are many studies piled up behind the names of each plant on Mount Hayachine. You can trace the connections between researchers from local to national levels."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters. The first chapter covers the history and beliefs of Mount Hayachine, and the second chapter focuses on the geological research of German geologists such as Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), who laid the foundation of Japanese geology, based on the geology of Mount Hayachine.
